Through discussions during monthly safety meetings, formal training, and quarterly emergency drills, plant operations and maintenance personnel will be properly trained in limited emergency response. As the situation warrants, the public will be notified through respective Public Affairs personnel at the Police, Fire and JXN Water Affiliates and the EOC. In the event telephone contact is not possible, emergency dispatch will be conducted using JXN Water-wide communication system.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Personnel training, equipment inspections and preventative maintenance will continue and be improved. Current plans follow Federal, State and Local regulations. Employees are committed to maintaining the most current and future regulations.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

JXN Water of Jackson is dedicated to the proper use of chemicals in a manner which is safer to the environment and people. Chemical storage areas and process equipment are regularly inspected, repaired and upgraded to prevent accidental releases. Should an accidental release occur, response activities will be coordinated through the Hinds County Emergency Operations Center and the Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality. On-site personnel are trained to make minor repairs and to contain small accidental releases.


Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled

The J.H. Fewell Water Treatment Plant withdraws water from the Pearl River, treats the water and supplies the water to a portion of JXN Water of Jackson. The plant uses chlorine gas mixed in water with anhydrous ammonia gas to disinfect the water. The chlorine gas is stored in 14 one-ton cylinders. At a given time, 7 of the cylinders are connected on a single header. The ammonia gas is stored in a 10,000-gallon above ground tank with a 2,000 gallon above ground tank used for backup.
Coordinates for the chemical storage locations at the plants were computed using EPAs downloadable Marplot tool referenced in Figures 1-1 through 1-4.


Worst-Case Release Scenarios

EPA mandates that the Worst-Case Release Scenarios have a release of the entire contents of the largest single container of each regulated substance during a 10-minute period with a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second and an F atmospheric stability class. Toxic Endpoint distances for releases were developed using the EPAs modeling software ALOHA version 5.4.7 while referencing tables listed in EPAs RMP Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants. The population affected by releases was computed using the EPAs and NOAAs Marplot 5.1.1 software which contains the year 2010 census data. EPA requires that a circle with a radius equal to the Toxic Endpoint be used to dete

rmine the area adversely affected by a release. EPA does not allow the circle to be modified to compensate for prevailing wind conditions or terrain effects, which would greatly reduce populated areas adversely affected by a release. For a 1-ton release of chlorine gas, the distance to the Toxic Endpoint as modeled is 1.72 miles, affecting approximately 10,204 residents, nearby major commercial areas of Jackson and Flowood, MS, the recreational area along the Pearl River, I-55 N, Lakeland Drive, hospitals, The Memorial Stadium, and Leflores Bluff State Park. The 10,000-gallon ammonia tanks are limited to being filled to 85% of capacity due to the policy of ammonia suppliers used by JXN Water, reducing the effective capacity of each tank to 8,500 gallons. For an 8,500-gallon release of ammonia gas, the distance to the Toxic Endpoint is 2.56 miles, which includes areas in Jackson, Pearl, and Flowood, Mississippi affecting approximately 23,265 residents and nearby schools, hospitals, major commercial areas, major government areas, the recreational area along the Pearl River, Lefleurs Bluff State Park, The Memorial Stadium, I-55 N, and Lakeland Drive.


Alternative Release Scenarios

As determined by ALOHA an atmospheric stability class of C was used since it matched Jacksons average weather parameters of temperature (83.7°F for August), humidity (74%), and wind speed (3.0 m/s). Chlorine gas was modeled as released through a 0.375? diameter hole in the supply piping with a valve that failed to close automatically for 1 cylinder was assumed. This produced a distance to the Toxic Endpoint of 1.16 miles, affecting approximately 3,705 residents, nearby major commercial areas of Jackson and Flowood, MS, the recreational area along the Pearl River, I-55 N, Lakeland Drive, hospitals, and Leflores Bluff State Park. The release scenario for ammonia storage assumed the release of the contents of the larger storage tank, producing a distance to the Toxic Endpoint of 1.

09 miles, affecting approximately 3,057 residents, the recreational area along the Pearl River, hospitals, and Lefleurs Bluff State Park.


General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Prevention Steps

The plant is manned 24 hours each day including holidays with at least two operators. These operators inspect the chlorine and ammonia systems at least twice each shift. The chlorine system has area gas monitors which trigger flashing lights and an audible alarm on the main plant computer in the Operations Room. The ammonia system has an area gas monitor in the Ammoniator Building which triggers a flashing light and an audible alarm in the building. The ammonia system also has high-pressure and low-pressure alarms which produce an audible alarm on the plant computer and a warning light on the plants control board. Maintenance personnel are immediately called in to stop small releases. The operation and maintenance of the chlorine and ammonia equipment are performed in accordance with the manufacturers instructions. Operations and maintenance personnel receive regular training in the use and maintenance of the equipment through monthly safety meetings, seminars provided by the equipment manufacturers and formal classes provided through the Mississippi Water and Pollution Control Operators Association and other training providers.


Five-Year Accident History

During the last five years, the plant has not had any releases of chlorine or ammonia which resulted in death, injury, property damage or environmental damage.


Emergency Response Program

The J.H. Fewell Water Treatment Plant has developed an emergency response program.
